table.name: Cranking Advance Table
table.description: CRADV table// Cranking Timing A

table.name: Consult Ignition Timing Adjustment Limits
table.description: These are the limits as to how far Consult can adjust the ignition timing. There's really no point in adjusting this limiter unless you're wanting to experiment or implement it in some other way.

table.name: Crank Fueling TP Value Table
table.description: This table bypasses the injector K value, so modifying this for larger injectors is essential. This table value DOES get multiplied by the Fuel Compensation Map Value! So you can also adjust the fuel compensation map to affect cranking fueling.

table.name: Target Idle Table
table.description: The main target idle table. This table sets the RPM target that the ECU will attempt to hit. Do note that changing the target values could have adverse effects due to the limiters in place. So if you make adjustments to this table, ensure that you're not breaching any of the set limits.

table.name: Idle BFS Limits
table.description: If your BFS at idle exceeds these values, it'll throw a P0507(5 or 607? the ISC one)

table.name: MAF Idle Voltage Limits
table.description: This is the voltage range the ECU expects to see from the MAF sensor at idle.

table.name: ISC Opening Area Upper Limit Table
table.description: ISC opening area upper limit value table

table.name: ISC Opening Area Upper Limit Table 2
table.description: ISC opening area upper limit value table 2

table.name: ISC Opening Area Upper Limit Table (RPM Compensation)
table.description: ISC opening area upper limit engine speed compensation table

table.name: ISC Opening Area Upper Limit Table 2 (RPM Compensation)
table.description: Value is added onto the ISC Opening Area Upper Limit Table value.

table.name: MAF Table
table.description: Inhalation air quantity conversion table. This table represents airflow through the MAF sensor at a given voltage. For stock MAF diameter intakes, I'd strongly recommend utilizing the MAF Factor alongside Fuel Compensation to dial in your fueling, rather than utilizing this table.

table.name: MAF Factor
table.description: Used in main fuel calc, can be used instead of adjusting K factor. This is what Nissan uses to scale MAF from factory.

table.name: Fuel Compensation Map (16x16)
table.description: This map will directly trim Base Fuel Schedule. Given how we have transient throttle fuel compensation maps, this map is really designed for steady state conditions with little RPM deviance. However, you can use this map to tune for transient conditions.

table.name: Steady State Judgement Smoothing Coefficient Map
table.description: At the time of the steady state judgement, smoothing coefficient map.

table.name: Load Base Fuel Schedule Table
table.description: The 100% BFS value based on RPM used to calculate "Calculated Load"0. This table is primarily used for vehicles equipped with an automatic transmission. You want to ensure that your calculated load parameter is reading 100% at WOT at all times. Since this value is the 100% value, all you need to do is lower each RPM's 100% BFS value until your WOT BFS exceeds this value.

table.name: Individual Cylinder Fuel Trims
table.description: This adds or subtracts fuel from the respective cylinder. Values over 100 add fuel, values under 100 subtract fuel.

table.name: Target AFR Map (8x8)
table.description: This map will be directly influence fueling. Any cells that are set to 14.7 AFR will have the ECU run in closed-loop mode. (Obviously excluding decel) This map will not guarantee that your targets are hit, so you will need to adjust your fueling elsewhere to ensure you're hitting your targets.

table.name: Target AFR Map (16x16)
table.description: This map will be directly influence fueling. Any cells that are set to 14.7 AFR will have the ECU run in closed-loop mode. (Obviously excluding decel) This map will not guarantee that your targets are hit, so you will need to adjust your fueling elsewhere to ensure you're hitting your targets.

table.name: Target AFR Table (High Detonation)
table.description: This Target AFR table will be used when knock is detected. It will utilize both the Target AFR Table and this Target AFR table to calculate the fueling. It's probably safe to leave this one how it is.

table.name: Closed Loop to Open Loop Delay
table.description: "All the delay stage delays" This value represents a maximum delay between the time the car goes from closed to open loop fuel target values. There are several other potential delays but setting this to 0 should override them. For performance applications to ensure that the ecu transitions to the fuel target as fast as possible upon wide open throttle, set to 0.

table.name: Fuel Compensation Map (Transient Throttle Deceleration)
table.description: Compensates fueling during deceleration.

table.name: Fuel Compensation Map (Transient Throttle Acceleration)
table.description: Compensates fueling during acceleration.

table.name: High Temperature Fuel Compensation Map
table.description: "A high coolant temperature increase map" Sets vKHOTMP and eventually vKHOT. Most likely just determines WHERE coolant compensation will take place. As it's a 0% or 100% by default, meaning 0% or 100% probably gets multiplied by the other coolant compensations.

table.name: High Coolant Temperature Increase Compensation Table
table.description: A high coolant temperature increase compensation table

table.name: Rev Limit (Fuel Cut - 3D)
table.description: These are the engine speeds at which the fuel cut rev limiter is engaged and disengaged. When engine speed is equal to or exceeds the 'On' value, fuel cut is active, after which, if engine speed drops below the 'Off' value, fueling is resumed.

table.name: Bosch Fuel Cut Table
table.description: "BOSCH cut speed table" This is the fuel cut table used for Bosch ECU's only. If the RPM's are above the cut speed, then fuel cut will occur (on decel) until the RPM's hit the recover speed.

table.name: JECS Fuel Cut Table
table.description: "JECS cut speed table" This is the fuel cut table used for JECS/Hitachi ECU's only. If the RPM's are above the cut speed, then fuel cut will occur (on decel) until the RPM's hit the recover speed.

table.name: Bosch Fuel Restore Table
table.description: "BOSCH cut recover rotation table" This is the recover speed table for the Bosch fuel cut.

table.name: JECS Fuel Restore Table
table.description: "JECS cut recover speed table" This is the recover speed table for JECS/Hitachi fuel cut.

table.name: KT Low Oil Temperature Fuel Cut/Restore
table.description: At the time of KT low oil temperature, all cylinder high rotation cut/recover judgement speed

table.name: Maximum Injector Pulsewidth Table
table.description: If your pulsewidth exceeds this value, fuel cut will occur.

table.name: Cylinder Filling Up Efficiency Scaler
table.description: BFS at which maximum airflow occurs. This value is used to setup ITAC as an estimated Volumetric Efficiency value. So if BFS=BFS Scaler, Cylinder Filling Up Efficiency = 100%. This CAN go above 100%, so ensure that you're never going over this value by too much.

table.name: K-Value
table.description: Global Fuel injection Multiplier. Value is used to convert a raw airflow amount into an injector pulsewidth per kilogram of air. To adjust this value for changes in fuel injector size, the formula is as follows: (0ld Injector Size -->New Injector Size) * Old K-Value = New K-Value.

table.name: Fuel Injector Latency Adder
table.description: This is the value in milliseconds that is added to the injector latency 14V table for every 1v drop in voltage. IE: if latency at 14v is 2ms and the adder is 1ms then the latency at 13v would be 3ms.

table.name: Minimum Injector Pulse Width
table.description: This is the minimum pulsewidth the injectors will run at. (Excluding fuel cut)

table.name: Short Term Fuel Trim Limits
table.description: These are the main STFT limits. I would not set these any lower than 85-115.

table.name: Cold Ignition Timing Map (16x16)
table.description: This is tied to coolant temp and only used when the coolant temp is under a certain set point.

table.name: High Octane Ignition Timing Map (16x16)
table.description: This is the main trimming map that the ECU uses when high-octane fuel is determined. The ECU calculates a MBT ignition advance, then this trimming map value is added/subtracted from that value. However, there are other compensations that occur as well.

table.name: High Detonation Ignition Timing Map (16x16)
table.description: This trimming map is used by the ecu when it detects high detonation. This map should ALWAYS be lower than the high octane map.

table.name: JAR Sound Compensation Table (Coolant Temperature)
table.description: JAR Sound = Piston Slap. These tables are used to retard ignition timing to prevent damage from occuring. I'd recommend using the Coolant Compensation Table for the MBT calculation instead. This value is subtracted from the Engine RPM Table value (below) to set vADVJAR. This value is subtracted from the timing value, so raising these values will cause the timing to be retarded. This value is ALWAYS USED to calculate timing (apart from idle and decel).

table.name: JAR Sound Compensation Table (Engine RPM)
table.description: JAR Sound = Piston Slap. These tables are used to retard ignition timing to prevent damage from occuring. I'd recommend using the main Ignition Timing Maps to compensate for RPM instead. This value has the mTADVC1 Table value subtracted from it before setting vADVJAR. So if you want these tables to compensate, you need to have this value be larger than the Coolant Comp value. Since the value gets subtracted, THESE VALUES CANNOT BE BELOW 0! If they're below 0, it'll just set the value to 0.

table.name: Ignition Timing Initial Value
table.description: "Ignition advance initial value." Only is used if fADV1ST "Beginning ADV operation completion flag" is set to 0. Since there's a cranking startup timing table, not sure when this would be used.

table.name: MBT Flame Speed Map
table.description: Laminar flow flame velocity basic map

table.name: Cylinder Fresh Air Rate Map
table.description: Sets wvITAN (and vITAN), which is used in MBT calculations.

table.name: Coolant Temperature MBT Compensation Table
table.description: Flame Speed Calculation. Multiplied by the mTFLFA Table value, then by the MBT Map value.

table.name: Coolant Temperature MBT Compensation Table 2
table.description: Flame Speed Calculation.

table.name: Target AFR MBT Compensation Table
table.description: Flame Speed Calculation. Multiplied by the mTFLTW Table value, then by the MBT Map value.

table.name: Target AFR MBT Compensation Table 2
table.description: Flame Speed Calculation. Multiplied by the mTFLTW Table value, then by the MBT Map value.

table.name: Unburned Gas Density Table
table.description: Table value is multiplied by vFLV (after AFR and Coolant compensations)

table.name: War Way Speed Weight Constant
table.description: MBT Calculation.

table.name: Dilution Modification Coefficient
table.description: MBT Calculation.

table.name: Ignition Timing Main Constant
table.description: Represents Standard Air Density * Cylinder Sweep Volume

table.name: Ignition Delay Time
table.description: MBT Calculation.

table.name: EGR Modification Coefficient
table.description: Flame Speed Calculation.

table.name: Dwell VB Coefficient
table.description: Dwell VB coefficient

table.name: Dwell TIM Coefficient
table.description: Dwell TIM coefficient

table.name: Dwell Limits
table.description: Dwell upper/lower limit value

table.name: GOV Table
table.description: Ignition timing value during idle/deceleration. Used when coolant temperature is below mGOVTW's value. (Stock = 131*F)

table.name: GOV3 Table
table.description: Ignition timing value during idle/deceleration. Used whenever the coolant temperature is above mGOVTW's value. (Stock = 131*F)

table.name: GOVL Table
table.description: Ignition timing value during idle/deceleration. Used for lean burn engines.

table.name: GOV Addition Table (Drive)
table.description: Value is added onto the GOV Table value when in drive.

table.name: GOV Addition Table (Neutral)
table.description: Value is added onto the GOV Table value when in neutral.

table.name: Time of Closed Loop, GOV-Neutral Compensation Table
table.description: Value is subtracted from the mTAVCN1 Table value

table.name: Time of PI Control, GOV-Neutral Compensation Table
table.description: Only used in open loop and if PI conditions are right (unknown atm). Value is then added to the mTAVCN1 Table value.

table.name: K2Y Table (Deceleration Advance)
table.description: These are apart of the vDLTADV ignition timing calculations :o Sets vK2Y.

table.name: K1 Table (Acceleration Retard)
table.description: These are apart of the vDLTADV ignition timing calculations :o Sets vK1.

table.name: Initial Retard Quantity Table
table.description: Used when accelerating.

table.name: Initial Retard Quantity Table (Idle)
table.description: Only used when accelerating from idle AND if vehicle speed is higher than ROM value. This table will NEVER be used stock because the value is set to 316mph. (Deceleration and idle)

table.name: Initial Retard Quantity Table (Lock-Up)
table.description: Only used when accelerating during lock-up.

table.name: Initial Retard Quantity Table (Fuel Cut)
table.description: Only used when accelerating from fuel cut.

table.name: Initial Retard Quantity Table (Fuel Cut Lock-Up)
table.description: Only used when accelerating from fuel cut and when lock-up is occurring.

table.name: Ignition Timing Compensation Retard Limiter
table.description: Ignition retard limiter used in the DLTADV calculation.

table.name: Ignition Timing Compensation Advance Limiter
table.description: Ignition advance limiter used in the DLTADV calculation.

table.name: VVT MBT Compensation Quantity Table
table.description: The deviance is based on how far the actual cam timing is from the target.

table.name: Ignition Adjustment Limits (Filling Up Efficiency)
table.description: Ignition adjustment value limits filling up efficiency

table.name: Ignition Adjustment Limits (Engine RPM)
table.description: Ignition adjustment value lower/upper limit speed

table.name: Consult Ignition Timing Adjustment Limits
table.description: These are the limits as to how far Consult can adjust the ignition timing. There's really no point in adjusting this limiter unless you're wanting to experiment or implement it in some other way.

table.name: Retard Side Maximum Change Width
table.description: Retard side maximum change width

table.name: Advance Side Maximum Change Width
table.description: Advance side maximum change width

table.name: Advance Side Maximum Change Width (Cranking)
table.description: Retard side maximum change width (When it starts.)

table.name: Retard Side Limiter
table.description: Retard Side Limiter

table.name: Advance Side Limiter
table.description: Advance side limiter

table.name: Ignition Timing Change Rate Limiter
table.description: Ignition timing change rate limiter

table.name: Cold Ignition Timing Map Knock Window
table.description: This is the knock window that determines whether the ECU will aggressively pull timing if knock is detected. So basically, if you're in the knock window and knock is detected, it'll pull timing and keep timing retarded from MBT for a bit while it waits to see if anymore knock occurs. If no more knock occurs, it'll slowly add timing back. If more knock occurs, it'll continue retarding timing.

table.name: High Octane Ignition Timing Map Knock Window
table.description: This is the knock window that determines whether the ECU will aggressively pull timing if knock is detected. So basically, if you're in the knock window and knock is detected, it'll pull timing and keep timing retarded from MBT for a bit while it waits to see if anymore knock occurs. If no more knock occurs, it'll slowly add timing back. If more knock occurs, it'll continue retarding timing.

table.name: High Detonation Ignition Timing Map Knock Window
table.description: This is the knock window that determines whether the ECU will aggressively pull timing if knock is detected. So basically, if you're in the knock window and knock is detected, it'll pull timing and keep timing retarded from MBT for a bit while it waits to see if anymore knock occurs. If no more knock occurs, it'll slowly add timing back. If more knock occurs, it'll continue retarding timing.

table.name: Knock Slice Map
table.description: This table sets the thresholds for determining knock by cylinder. If the knock strength value exceeds this map value, then it adds one to the knock count. For built motors, you'll need to raise these values so that it doesn't count false knock as actual knock.

table.name: High Octane Knock Limit Map
table.description: This table sets the limits of knock retard correction when high-octane fuel is determined.

table.name: High Detonation Knock Limit Map
table.description: This table sets the limits of knock retard correction when high detonation occurs.

table.name: Cold Intake Cam Timing Map (8x8)
table.description: Cold Intake Cam Timing map.

table.name: Intake Cam Timing Map (16x16)
table.description: Controls the intake VVT cam angles. The ECU uses a PID control (PI, P?) system to have the actual cam angles hit this target cam angle. It's highly recommended to avoid having large jumps between cells, as the PID control system could get overwhelmed and cause problems. While this map is the only one that affects idle, CF48D has a lower limit vehicle speed of 2mph before VVT will be activated.

table.name: High Detonation Intake Cam Timing Map (4x4)
table.description: VTC target operation angle regular compensation value computed map. This is only used when knock is detected.

table.name: Exhaust Cam Timing Map (16x16)
table.description: Retarding of the exhaust camshaft in degrees.

table.name: VVT Drive Abnormality Diagnosis Judgement Delay Map
table.description: VTC drive abnormality diagnosis judgement delay

table.name: P-Gain Computed Map (Bank 1)
table.description: The left bank P-gain gain computed map // Cam Timing

table.name: P-Gain Computed Map (Bank 2)
table.description: P-gain gain computed map// Cam Timing

table.name: Throttle Rev Limiter
table.description: Engine speed at which the throttle rev limiter is engaged and disengaged.

table.name: Speed Limiter
table.description: The speed at which throttle cut occurs. For automatics, be sure to change the fuel cut speed limiters as well.

table.name: Speed Limiter (Fuel Cut)
table.description: Primarily used in automatics. It's the speed at which fuel cut will occur. It's normally set above the throttle cut speed limiter, so you're unlikely to ever hit this stock.

table.name: Speed Limiter (Fuel Restore)
table.description: Ensure that this value is below the fuel cut speed limiter's value.

table.name: QH0/ Torque Conversion Map
table.description: Directly influences throttle opening.

table.name: QH0/ Torque Conversion Map 2
table.description: Directly influences throttle opening.

table.name: TTEPTD Torque Compensation Map
table.description: This map acts as a multiplier for the QH0 Torque Conversion Map value. If the multiplied value exceeds the last column value of the QH0 map, then it'll just use the last column value of the QH0 map instead.

table.name: Throttle Body Opening Area Calibration Table
table.description: Sets vATVO (RAM)

table.name: Throttle Flow Potential Table
table.description: Used to calculate a QH0 Flow Potential value to determined the APO Requested Torque. (QH0/ Torque Conversion Map) Nissan has these tables setup identically across all the ROM's I've checked, so you really don't need to touch these.

table.name: Throttle Flow Potential Table 2
table.description: Table MUST be identical to the first one!

table.name: Throttle Flow Potential Table (High Flow-Quantity)
table.description: Used to calculate a QH0 Flow Potential value to determined the APO Requested Torque. (QH0/ Torque Conversion Map) Nissan has these tables setup identically across all the ROM's I've checked, so you really don't need to touch these.

table.name: Throttle Flow Potential Table 2 (High Flow-Quantity)
table.description: Table MUST be identical to the first one!

table.name: APO Threshold (Brake)
table.description: The APO threshold you need to breach in order to trigger the TVO limiter when the brake is currently being applied. Raising this threshold above ~83 degrees will allow you to bypass this TVO limiter.

table.name: TVO Upper Limit Table
table.description: If this value is greater than 79.97 degrees, then it'll just use 79.97 degrees as the upper limiter.

table.name: TVO Upper Limit Table 2
table.description: A throttle open-degree upper limit speed table (a main operation part) for the intake pulsation countermeasure

table.name: ATRET Limit
table.description: Seems to be the retard limit for vATRET calculations. So adjusting this will allow timing to be retarded to whatever you want.

table.name: Engine Torque Map
table.description: Map value is compensated, then sent to the TCM for it to determine proper line pressure. Raising the values will result in increased line pressure, while decreasing the values will result in decreased line pressure. It's important to ensure that the map values are at LEAST equal to actual torque output. While it's safe to specify higher torque figures than what you're making, it's extremely dangerous to specify lower torque figures than what you're making.

table.name: Gear Ratio Table 2
table.description: Table values must match the first table's values.

table.name: Torque Converter Torque Ratio Table
table.description: Torque converter torque ratio table// Axis vNSLPRT

table.name: Torque Converter Torque Ratio Table 2
table.description: Torque converter torque ratio table// Axis vNSLPRT_S

table.name: TCS Fuel Cut Prohibition Speed Table
table.description: This table sets the RPM threshold that has to be breached before the TCS can cut fuel. If RPM's drop below the table value, fueling will be restored.

table.name: Fuel Cut Extreme Short Rest Time Map
table.description: An extreme short rest time map

table.name: Fuel Cut Suspension Time:Operation Time Ratio Map
table.description: Suspension time/operation time ratio map

table.name: AFR Correction Map (Bank 1)
table.description: This value is added on top of the AFR value from the AFR Conversion Table.

table.name: AFR Correction Map (Bank 2)
table.description: This value is added on top of the AFR value from the AFR Conversion Table.

table.name: AFR Conversion Table
table.description: Tells the ECU what wideband voltage equals what AFR. Axis is AFR Sensor Voltage after atmospheric pressure compensation.

table.name: CID1100 supmask
table.description: mSCID10

table.name: CID1120 supmask
table.description: mSCID12

table.name: CID1140 supmask
table.description: mSCID14

table.name: CID1160 supmask
table.description: mSCID16

table.name: CID1200 supmask
table.description: mSCID20

table.name: CID1220 supmask

bit.name: 34 Diag 1 Coolant temperature sensor function diagnosis Rate counter
37 Diag 4 A counter for vehicle speed sensor diagnosis frequency measuring
38 Diag 5 Fuel temperature sensor diagnosis diagnosis complete counter
39 Diag 6 A counter for neutral SW diagnosis frequency measuring
3A Diag 7 0.04-inch leak diagnosis frequency measuring counter
3B Diag 8 Line pressure sensor function diagnosis frequency measuring counter
3C Diag 9 Lambda control close diagnosis Rate counter
3D Diag 10 Intake air temperature diagnosis complete counter
3F Diag 12 Fuel level gauge function diagnosis RATE counter

table.description: mSCID22

table.name: CID1240 supmask

bit.name: 41 A counter (for the RATE law) for ISC function diagnosis frequency measuring
43 A counter for purge system diagnosis frequency measuring
44 A counter (bank 1) for RrO2 sensor diagnosis frequency measuring
45 A counter (bank 2) for RrO2 sensor diagnosis frequency measuring

table.description: mSCID24

table.name: CID1301 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1302 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1303 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1304 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1305 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1306 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1307 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1308 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1309 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID130A supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID130B supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID130C supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID130D supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID130E supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID130F supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1310 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1311 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1312 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1313 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1314 supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: CID1420 Supmask
table.description: mSCID16

table.name: CID1500 Supmask
table.description: mSCID50

table.name: OBD-2 PID 01-20 supmask

bit.name: 01 Status since the last clearing of fault codes
02 Fault code that caused the recording of 'freeze frame' data
03 Fuel System Status (Open Loop/Closed Loop I believe)
0B Intake manifold absolute pressure in kPa
12 Status of the secondary intake circuit
14 AFR Sensor 1 B1 (V?) Alpha might affect
18 AF Sensor 2 B2 (V?) Alpha might affect
1C OBD Computer Specification (mGM1P1C, just a value of 1. Maybe 0, 1, 2 or something alters some functionality?)

table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: OBD-2 PID 21-40 supmask

bit.name: 21 Distance travelled with MIL on in kms
22 Relative fuel rail pressure in kPa
24 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 1, sensor 1 (lambda and volts)
25 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 1, sensor 2 (lambda and volts)
26 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 1, sensor 3 (lambda and volts)
27 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 1, sensor 4 (lambda and volts)
28 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 2, sensor 1 (lambda and volts)
29 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 2, sensor 2 (lambda and volts)
2A O2 sensor (extended range) bank 2, sensor 3 (lambda and volts)
2B O2 sensor (extended range) bank 2, sensor 4 (lambda and volts)
30 Number of warning(s) since faults (DTC) were cleared
32 Evaporation system vapour pressure in Pa
34 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 1, sensor 1 (lambda and volts)
35 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 1, sensor 2 (lambda and volts)
36 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 1, sensor 3 (lambda and volts)
37 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 1, sensor 4 (lambda and volts)
38 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 2, sensor 1 (lambda and volts)
39 O2 sensor (extended range) bank 2, sensor 2 (lambda and volts)
3A O2 sensor (extended range) bank 2, sensor 3 (lambda and volts)
3B O2 sensor (extended range) bank 2, sensor 4 (lambda and volts)

table.description: bits enable/disable

table.name: OBD-2 PID 41-60 Supmask
table.description: bits enable/disable

rom.table: 0x80 0x40 0x20 0x10 0x08 0x04 0x02 0x01 mFPCUT- A hand-operated purge cut flag

table.name: The Whole Area Torque Going Down Control Switching Flag

rom.table: 0x80 0x40 0x20 0x10 0x08 0x04 0x02 0x01 mTDRQARI2- The whole area torque going down control switching flag

0x80 0x40 0x20 0x10 0x08 0x04 0x02 0x01 Controls what O2 sensors the ECU thinks it has. Disabling any of them will cause said sensor to no longer be utilized by the ECU. (MIGHT need to force emission readiness, as it'll probably show "not supported" for catalyst monitoring)

0x80 0x40 0x20 0x10 0x08 0x04 0x02 0x01 Disabling the ETC Control flag will cause the throttle to be 1:1 with the accelerator. I would highly recommend against disabling it, as you would be removing the incredible advantages DBW has over cable driven throttles.

table.name: Cruise Control, PTD Open-Degree Operation Switching Flag
